claim: The United States has fewer guns per capita than Australia.

supporting.text: The United States has one of the highest rates of civilian gun ownership in the world, with approximately 120.5 firearms per 100 residents as of 2025, according to small arms surveys.

attacks.text: The United States has one of the highest rates of civilian gun ownership in the world, with approximately 120.5 firearms per 100 residents as of 2025, according to small arms surveys.
Australia has significantly lower gun ownership rates, with only about 14.5 firearms per 100 residents as of 2025, according to the same small arms surveys.
The claim compares per capita gun ownership, not absolute numbers, making the high U.S. rate directly relevant to disproving the claim.
Some regions in Australia, like rural areas, may have higher gun ownership rates, potentially skewing the national average.
The small arms survey data may not account for unregistered firearms, which could be higher in Australia than reported.

supporting.text: Australia, in contrast, has strict gun control laws implemented after the 1996 Port Arthur massacre, resulting in a much lower rate of gun ownership, estimated at around 14.5 firearms per 100 residents as of 2025.

attacks.text: Australia, in contrast, has strict gun control laws implemented after the 1996 Port Arthur massacre, resulting in a much lower rate of gun ownership, estimated at around 14.5 firearms per 100 residents as of 2025.

attacks.text: The U.S. Second Amendment protects the right to bear arms, leading to a cultural and legal environment that encourages higher gun ownership compared to Australia, where such protections do not exist.
